Intelligence¶

Implements agent PGT intelligence for SemiNFG objects

Part of: PyNFG - a Python package for modeling and solving Network Form Games

Created on Mon Feb 25 12:07:49 2013

Copyright (C) 2013 James Bono (jwbono@gmail.com)

GNU Affero General Public License

pynfg.pgtsolutions.intelligence.iq.iq_MC(G, S, X, M, noise, integrand=None, mix=False)[source]¶

Run MC outer loop on random policies for SemiNFG IQ calcs

Parameters:
  • G (SemiNFG) – the semiNFG to be evaluated
  • S (int) – number of policy profiles to sample
  • X (int) – number of samples of each policy profile
  • M (int) – number of random alt policies to compare
  • integrand (func) – a user-supplied function of G that is evaluated for each s in S
  • pure – True if restricting sampling to pure strategies. False if mixed strategies are included in sampling. Default is True.

Note

This is the agent-approach because intelligence is assigned to a DN instead of being assigned to a player.

pynfg.pgtsolutions.intelligence.iq.iq_MH(G, S, X, M, noise, density, integrand=None, mix=False)[source]¶

Run MH for SemiNFG with IQ calcs

Parameters:
  • G (SemiNFG) – the SemiNFG to be evaluated
  • S (int) – number of MH iterations
  • noise (float) – the degree of independence of the proposal distribution on the current value. 1 is independent, 0 returns no perturbation.
  • density (func) – the function that assigns weights to iq
  • X (int) – number of samples of each policy profile
  • M (int) – number of random alt policies to compare
  • delta (float) – the discount factor
  • integrand (func) – a user-supplied function of G that is evaluated for each s in S
  • mix – if true, proposal distribution is over mixed CPTs. Default is False.

Note

This is the agent-approach because intelligence is assigned to a DN instead of being assigned to a player.

pynfg.pgtsolutions.intelligence.iq.iq_calc(dn, G, X, M)[source]¶

Calc IQ of policy at dn in G

Parameters:
  • dn (str) – the name of the DN to be evaluated
  • G (SemiNFG) – the semiNFG to be evaluated
  • X (int) – number of samples of each policy profile
  • M (int) – number of random alt policies with which to compare
